claim.text: Combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12% along with reduction in gender bias learned by audio-based neural networks by over 30%.
claim.exact_quote: combining tabular data from financial semi-structured documents with text transcripts and audio recordings improves stock volatility and price movement prediction by 5-12% along with reduction in gender bias learned by audio-based neural networks by over 30%

evidence.evidence_text: Ablation analysis of M3A model augmented with DocEmbedding for each modality shows best performance when combining audio, text and tabular data.
evidence.limitations: Limited to situations where modalities are combined; does not account for data unavailability or quality issues.
evidence.exact_quote: Combining audio, text and tabular data gives best performance

evidence.evidence_text: Utilizing text transcripts with table data from financial documents instead of its audio counterpart does not deteriorate the model performance, which suggests an effective alternative to audio input for reducing gender bias without significant performance degradation.
evidence.limitations: Based on an ablation study, it might not generalize across all possible datasets or scenarios.
evidence.exact_quote: utilizing text transcripts with table data from financial documents instead of its audio counterpart does not deteriorate the model performance

evaluation.justification: The evidence provided multiple aspects of experimental data to support the claim, though it's based on specific datasets and methods.
evaluation.key_limitations: Experiment-centric and dataset-specific; gender bias reduction specific to the case study on financial calls.
